Important to mention, you see the tractor spool prior to launch. That is done to launch under load so the turbo spools for a power launch. The tractor wouldn't be able to move like that otherwise. Basically, it all boils down to ignition control. An two-step rev limiter lets you set one (lower) limiter for launch, and a higher limit for when you're upshifting as you accelerate away.

The guy said “air is what controls a Diesel engine”. Actually, UNLIKE a petrol engine where engine speed is controlled by the amount of air coming in, diesel engine speed is controlled by fuel.

This is why petrol engines have a throttle body on the air intake systems that is directly connected to the accelerator pedal (physically or electronically) and Diesel engines have a fuel rack connected to the accelerator in the same manner. When you want more power in a gas engine, your throttle body allows the engine to suck in more air, when you want more power in a Diesel engine you’re fuel rack allows for the flow of more fuel.

Now, both engines require a balance of both of course, but how they do it is also different. In a petrol engine, your on board computer will get data from multiple sensors telling it that it needs to add more fuel due to the influx of air. In a Diesel, as the engine speeds up, it just naturally sucks in the amount of air it requires.

They made it sound a lot more complicated than it is. Most people just say friction. It's called a transfer sled because it transfers the weight from over the tires, where it's a low-friction, rolling load, to over the skidplate, where it's a high-friction, dead load.
You're not going to find guys using physics to weight the tractor, they're looking at what other guys are doing and experimenting from there.
How straight it goes down track has nothing to do with power. A low tire can, or more likely a slick spot in the track will, cause that. It's easily remedied by moving a couple hundred pounds to the side that everyone ahead of you is driving off of, at THE BACK of the tractor.  I've seen a JD G make the same turn as 1066s at 9500 pounds, and it usually won that class.
I've moved as little as 250 pounds from center right to far left at the back, and had the only tractor to go straight down the track.
Most of these guys are spending cubic money having parts custom built. It takes a lot more creativity making factory parts fit non-factory applications in antique or farm stock, and you get a lot more bang for your buck.  These guys won't make 8 or 9 hooks in a day, let alone go somewhere else and make another 3 or 4 or 5 that evening.

Top fuel drag racing is all about explosive speed. Tractor pulls are about explosive power.

Modified tractor pulls are an underrated Motorsport. Growing up, I had always been a drag racing and road course fan. I hadn’t seen a modified pull till I met my wife, who was a driver along with the rest of her family. I though top fuel dragsters were impressive, but when you got 2000 hp ww2 aircraft engines, jet engines, or tractors with 4 or 5 alcohol injected V8s on a single frame, things get wild.

And let me tell you, the pros in the league are just as technical if not more then any NHRA or NASCAR crew. You think tuning a car is hard. Imagine tuning 5 separate engines to run completely synced to each other.

I'm from Lawrenceburg, TN. I know several of these pullers personally. An easy way to explain a sled is by it's technical name: a weight transfer machine. How cool is that! Cool to see you doing smarter every day with tractor pulling! BTW: in your drawing you draw that chain connection between tractor and sled is flat, which is wrong. Hooking point tractor side is 20 inch above ground (rule). Sledside it is on the bottom (rule). So with that angle in the chain (46 inch long, also a rule), you're getting weight on the rear of the tractor, which actually make the tires to hook as they do. So... I live in CA and literally days before this video, tractor pulls showed up in my feed. I was like... "What?" and then here comes Destin. It is like he read my mind.

Basically tractor pulling requires a few things. One- you need as much weight out front as possible. Two- you want the highest hitch height they allow. 3- you do not want to bounce(if you do you’ll most likely break). Four- the first 70ish feet you want to get as much momentum as possible without straight spinning your wheels. Five- your tires don’t need to be crazy, ask any professional truck/tractor puller they would prefer worn out tires over brand new

It’s just like with NHRA (Drag Racing) and NASCAR (Stock Car Racing), it may look pretty easy to the layperson, but then you try your hand at it yourself and find out very quickly that it’s not as easy as it looks.

By the way, Destin. Have you ever considered going to a NASCAR race or an NHRA event?

The height of the axle doesn't matter.  The forward force is coming from the tire contact patch on the ground.  The rearward force is coming from the trailer hitch.  The distance between those two forces, the moment arm, is 20".  That is countered by the distance from the tractor's center of gravity forward of the tire contact times the weight of the tractor.

I couldn't help it, I laughed a few times... My Grandpa, Lloyd Douglas, RIP.   From Dallas City, Il...was a TRUE pioneer of the sport, he helped design and build the very first transfer sleds with Ollie Schaeffer and the Luedke Family, One of the sleds I remember was the JUDGE, it read, "Here Comes Da JUDGE!!" on the side.  He was also one of the first announcers, and probably had more time on a microphone than Howard Cossell... before that he made the very FIRST sled. He flattened out a big metal tank off an old oil truck, into the shape of a toboggan. Men would line both sides of the track, and jump on as it went by, holding on to each other tight I'm sure.. the farther down the track, more men, more weight, until they stopped the tractor, YEEHAA, I actually remember some like that!! He pulled the first gasoline burning, diesel tractor with 4 turbochargers, yep, 4, an old Cockshut Super 570 in the 5000 and 7000lb Super Stock Class. He was called.. "Super Cecil Diesel"  and that tractor is still being driven in local parades by another relative. He pulled the ole Cockshut Super for 16 yrs, then became the lead announcer for The National Tractor Pullers Association and Agri-Shows, From the Dairyland Grand Nationals to the Superdome, for another 11 years!!. As well as many Stock Car Races and Air Shows.  He was even involved in the build of the very first BigFoot monster truck, and was instrumental in the introduction of Truck Pulls and the modern versions of the Monster Trucks.... AND I got to spend as much time on the road with him and Grandma as Mom would allow! The whole time I was growing up, I knew every puller, EVERY tractor, and they knew me... It was really like a big family ...  I miss those days and I really miss them, but Lord thank you for blessing me with the time spent and memories I still cherish..... and all that was a small fraction of his accomplishments... MY GRANDPA, MY HERO

As being a former puller myself, there is a whole lot of science that goes into it. One thing about weights that weren't mentioned is 100lbs hanging off the front can be worth a lot more weight than if mounted over the rear axle. The tractor is nothing more than a simple lever, with the rear tires being the fulcrum. When you put weights on the front, that is like putting weight on the end of a lever, and as long as you have enough power and traction to lift the front and transfer that weight, it adds more to the rear wheels than if that same weight was on the back.

Balancing act is a good description for nearly every aspect of one of these events.
The guys that build the track try to find a balance that works well for multiple classes, and won't change too much over the course of the evening or especially during a class.
The sled operator looks at the track and his notes to decide what weight and gear combination he needs to stop each class of vehicles very close to 300-320'.
The competitor has to choose where to put weight , air pressure, what gear to run, where to spot the sled and decide how quickly to apply power.
I definitely enjoyed the video but it does just scratch the surface of what goes into truck and tractor pulling.

We have these all over NW-Europe as well, i always liked the amateur classes, 40 year old juiced up diesel engines with all kinds of jerry-rigged mods, built by guys who usually maintain those machines to provide us with food. Also the fact that they have to run 'regular' tractor tyres with the deep tread. I just prefer races with vehicles close to their real-world counterparts.

My uncle is a farmer, he took his kids and nephews out to these events, we also got to ride along his machines all the time, my favorites were the beet-harvester and combines, I used to know all the names of all the machines when i was a kid, which is crazy to me because i don't know half of them as an adult.

I still go over there during harvests to help out, it's always so great to see all the local farmers helping eachother out getting those harvests in in time before the weather changes. It is such a different community and way of life compared to the rest of the modern world. Even the machine repairshops and such aren't corporate entities, but people who are actually connected to their customer base.

comment_text: Destin, I would like to see you do a video that solves this argument.  You made a comment about the drawbar height in relationship to the axel height, which give me the impression that you think the tractor pivots at the axel (a common misconception).  I am an old tractor puller from the 70's and 80's and I always took the position that the tractor pivots where the tire meets the ground.  It seems that this must be true since the tractor wheelies even though the drawbar is below the axel.  My other comment is about the tire lugs being shaved off: you get about the same shear as a taller lug, but the advantage of the shorter is less dirt is piled up in front of the sled.  Great video, tractor pulling is a fascinating physics topic in so many ways.

The physics is simple. Through the rear wheels' contact, the earth pulls the assembly forward. The hitch 20" above ground pulls back. the two forces form a 'moment couple" that is a torque that tends to lift the tractor pivoting about the tire-to-earth contact point. The torque is simply the pulling force times 20 inches. I don't see that the axle location has anything to do with it.

Destin Sandlin. Government Agent

Born and raised in Chattanooga, TN.; aka the, "Southern Silicon Valley." The south is so misunderstood. The people here are resourceful, hardy, honest people who work through respect, courtesies, and traditions. There's a reason the government used Restone Arsenal, Oak Ridge, and Tullahoma for some of their most classified activities because we know how to keep our mouths shut. Sure, there's problems here, but that's growing pains from a earlier time. The South is unique, and I'm proud to call it home despite its scars and bruises. We also happen to be some of the remaining, "Free States."

On a side note, while we are typically stereotyped for being slow talkers with incomprehensible drawls, the stereotype is actually because of historic widespread hookworm infestations. Look it up!

8:26 - The simplest way to think about it is that the sled is a lever. A lever can lift a weight closer to the crux than farther away from it. Think of it this way. The sled is a lever like a crow bar. It would be far easier to lift 50lbs down at the end of the crowbar near the fork, than to lift 50lbs out at the end near your hand. You are the tractor. ;-)

5:20 - I hope I'm understanding this wrong. He seems to have said that HE controls how fast the box moves forward. I always thought that the forward motion of the sled translated into forward motion of the box. If the tractor pulls faster, the box goes faster. If the tractor goes slower, the box goes slower. So that any way you do it, the box travels x number feet forward for X feet forward of the sled (or tractor). But if Brian controls the forward movement of the box, then the trial is different for each different tractor and you no longer have an equal comparison, or equal competition. Brian can give more forward motion for Tractor 1, than he does for Tractor 2. Hope I'm wrong about this.

Btw, the sled doesn't always win. When I was younger, I witnessed a 90+ year old tractor go the distance. A single cylinder, steam tractor, producing a total of 75hp, to add insult to injury.
At the time, the tractor pull was being held at our county fair. Also that day was an exhibition of antique gas and steam tractors. After a day of watching screaming, multi-engine, massively over powered tractors challenge and lose to the sled, the owner of said steam tractor asked if he could give it a try. Yeah, everyone laughed, but hooked him up anyway. Off he went, at a blistering 2 mph or so. Chug. Hiss. Chug. Hiss. Chug. And he kept going, and going, and going. He covered the entire length of the track with absolutely no trouble, right up to the very end. He could have kept going if he had wanted to, but stopped when he decided he was done.

So growing up, every summer I would go up to my mother's hometown which has an annual steam and tractor show. As my grandfather was one of the main organizers of the show, and so my family always got roped into helping out.  Over the years, my mother side of the family would dwindle down until it was just me and my Aunt who would run this peddle tractor pull. Now the thing with the peddle tractor and the sled for the pull is that my Grandfather built them.  And they were a blast to peddle around on even when i was well into my early twenties. But they were like well engineered machines, that were built but it was always the sled the got my attention. It was just a simple machine that when you engaged the clutch on it as the wheels moved on the back it would drive a chain and move the weights closer to the top, and as such create more force on the pan creating more friction, and thus more resistance to over come (i haven't seen the video yet so my apologies, if it is covered or my assumption is wrong.) But i would like to add to this one learning i took about why my assumption was that it is friction and resistance caused by the weights getting closer to the pan. One year when I was still competing in the peddle tractor pull, we got over 160 lbs (mechanical advantage from gears helped i guess) but we were pretty heavy and my uncle was getting tired of thia going on. So he runs and comes back with a chain. And attached the chain to the sled. So once the chain drags under the sled and the weight moves above the pan. It digs into the ground deeper making more resistance to over come.  Anyways that chain was humbling children ever since.

Fun fact, the tractor pull originated in my home town of Lynden, WA. Threshing bees added tractors and some smart farmers came up with the sled system to prove to each other who’s tractor was better. One-up-manship got a bit out of hand until people were slapping five or six big block engines on one tractor and ripping across the fields. The Northwest WA Fair began holding the big pulls at their grandstands. Even had a few go blasting through and end up crossing Kok road, landing in a farmer’s field.

I have family that live in Western Massachusetts, in the middle of the Appalachian Mountains. Every year their town has a small festival and the main attraction is a Tractor Pull. One Year I asked them why they have this event when there are no large farms. My cousin said that they live very far away from large cities and the infrastructure that they have. So they have to be self-sufficient to a large degree. Especially in winter or storms when it can take days for large plows to get to their town.

So when a tree falls on the road, which happens a lot, they will have to move it themselves to open up the road. This is where those tractors come in and provide an invaluable service in clearing roads for traffic, which allows ambulances and electrical company power trucks to get through to the people that need them.

Ever since I have respected these Tractor Pulls because while they can be viewed as simple entertainment, they are also practice for potentially life saving services. Services which have contributed to keeping my own family safe in winter and after Hurricane Sandy.

Soft spots in the track, if the pressure in the tires is different it'll pull to the side, engine torque as mentioned... like I said think twice before assuming these are simple country folk.. also that critical balance point of  Floating the front wheels is what maintains the bite on the tires or  shear force as you technically call it if the front of the tractor comes up too high it not only hits the wheelbars but the chain on the sled is now straight the chain is mounted lower on the sled so the 20" draw bar height creates some downward Pull That's why it's so critical to get the tractor to wheelie  And keep the front end properly weigted when the  Sled chain goes straight from too much wheelie you lose all your attraction and spin out, If the tractor does not wheelie at all you never had enough traction

Destin, I loved loved loved this video! So the "soil science" you guys talk about in the video is called "terramechanics" which is a subset of the more generic "soil mechanics." For the pieces we're interested in, with regard to the video, a scientist named Mieczysław G. Bekker developed equations to describe the shear strength of the soil which were further refined by another scientist Jo Y. Wong. (It's worth mentioning that Bekker was also involved in developing the Lunar Roving Vehicles.) So, with the Bekker-Wong equations, we can develop a curve for fairly accurately predicting soil behavior and therefore traction with a few inputs. The guys in the video with the sticks: they were performing crude bevameter tests which is a way of measuring and characterizing the shear strength of the soil. They were testing the soil and through experience and intuition getting the information that normally a ton of math would get you! This stuff could practically have its own video, the interaction our vehicles have with the ground is so complicated, unintuitive, and fascinating that I just love it.

One thing that I try to wrap my head around right now:

The rear tires of the tractor transmit their torque to the ground, with the torque working into the rotational direction the tire is actually spinning.
The reactional torque on the actual tractor itself around its rear axle goes the opposite way, meaning that the front of the tractor effectively goes up by the torque created by the traction.

The chain on the drawbar pulls below the rear axle to the rear which also creates a torque going the same rotational direction as the tires are spinning.
The reactional torque on the tractor created by that torque is the opposite way again, pulling up the front of the tractor even more.

If the drawbar was actually above the rear axle, the torque created by the drawbar would be the opposite way, meaning that it would counteract a part ot the torque created by the motor, meaning that the front would be lifted up less.
Am I right so far, in theory?

In Europe we like to use low and as close to the rear axle positioned drawbars on tractors.
But only for trailers that actually put quite a bit of vertical nose weight onto the drawbar, helping to increase the weight on the rear axle of the tractor.
Right now I can't wrap my head around why it is actually benefitial to have the drawbar positioned so low in this case.
But I guess it is just too late and time for bed.

One of the greatest material inventions has to be the rubber tire. Think of the forces it must be able to withstand and resistance to wear from incredibly abrasive surfaces - and to stay flexible and airtight through over a 150F range!
Some physics problems to consider:
1. All of those hundreds -> thousands of horsepower are translated through a 3-4" axel shaft to a tire that is ~ 6 feet in diameter -what is the torque and minimum sheer strength of the axel?
2. Estimate the surface area of the rubber in contact with the rim, then calculate the minimum coefficient of friction between the rubber and rim to prevent slippage with 1000 horsepower turning the wheel.

I remember as a kid (about 35 yrs ago) at the National Fieldays in Hamilton NZ, they had a tractor pull that seems a lot simpler. It was basically a race. The tractors just had to pull a weighted sled the length of the track and whoever did it fastest was the winner. The tractors were handicapped in a manner of speaking, the more horsepower your tractor, the greater the weight they put on the sled. Now, at the end of the competition, they decided to run the fastest tractor against a pair of Clydesdale horses. The fieldays are always in the winter and by the end of the competition the track was very muddy, about ankle deep. This ‘super’ tractor obviously had a lot of horsepower and consequently a very heavy sled, the two horses were obviously 2 horsepower and had an empty sled. Now when they started off, the horses were able to plunge their hooves down through the mud and get traction on the firm soil under the mud but the tractor had real trouble spinning in the mud. The result was that the horses won and were well  on their way through a victory lap before the tractor had reached the end. Needless to say, the crowd went wild.

comment_text:
Around the 20:00 mark you state that the sled moves as a function of distance. I think that's not quite true. They are highly related as wheel rotation and sled speed are mechanically coupled. However, differences in tread and tire pressure as well as different patterns of acceleration will result in differential amounts of distance gained per tire rotation.

Sled movement is a function of RPM, but not distance.

20:30 The height of the axle off the ground doesn't really matter*. The hitch point will always be higher than where the wheels contact the ground so there will always be a torque trying to lift the front end.

There seems to be a very common misconception that if you hitch below the axle that you are safe from tipping over. While it is true that being lower than the axle is much better than above, it is only the distance above the ground, and the tractive force that determines that torque. If you ran smaller wheels so that the axle was lower but kept the hitch height the same the torque acting to lift the front of the tractor would not change.

* Of course, a higher axle means larger diameter tires - which means a greater contact patch so that part certainly does matter - but for a given amount of tractive force, the location of the axle is irrelevant.

9:19. This might be the most important part of the video for me. I can still remember being 6 or 7 and shaking a man's hand with my left. He was a huge logging dude, hands the size of canned hams, a monster. He said: "son, no, no, no." Then explained the reason it was important and what must be done in order for people to respect you and take you seriously. Eye contact, firm grip, never seated, stand up straight and get your left hand out of your pocket. I will never forget that lesson. It has gotten me jobs and out of jams.

While in high school I lived half an hour north of Detroit. It was a car racing culture. Muscle cars, drag racing, you get the idea. While I loved the machinery and the skill of the drivers, to tell the truth I wasn't impressed with the silly speeds and the extreme hazard. I wanted it to be more about the humans and the machines, and less about the danger. I preferred go-cart racing, BMX, flat-track dirt racing (cars & bikes), and, as a guilty pleasure, demolition derby. I also liked monster trucks, which may be a very special case of people over raw power, but it seemed a little showy, rather than truly competitive.

One summer while visiting cousins in Indiana I got to watch my first tractor pull, and it all came together for me. Massive power, delicate control, low speeds, tremendous crowd appeal, great safety. I was surprised to learn there were tractor pulls going on in Michigan, but that community didn't overlap much with the one I was in. That changed!
I haven't spent much time in the South, but what little I have... it's no surprise y'all got us to the moon and back.

This video is very timely for me. See, I am a city boy originally from Michigan who moved, after college, to the evilness of Southern California for 33 years and in 2020, my wife and I came to our senses and moved our family to Hendersonville, TN. Last Saturday, I saw my first tractor pull ever at the Tennessee State Fair In Lebanon, TN. Here are a few of my thoughts.

1. I get the power part of tractor pulling but speed is a component also. The faster they get off the line and down the track before the sled sets down, it seems to me the further they go. So, why not have a couple of gears to get them down fast and then change for power.

2. It seems to me that they are competing over only a couple of inches. Therefore, although I thought it was cool with all the power and raw engine noise, at some point I got a little bored because as far as I could tell, they were all pulling about the same distance. Now, I only was there for the souped up pickup trucks. Maybe if I was there for the big tractors I would think differently.

3. I get a kick out of Destin. He can turn on and off the hillbilly just as quickly as a person fluent in two languages can switch between them. He’s good in the city or barefoot on the dirt roads in the hills.

The variety in sleds is also pretty vast. They start at literally just sleds with weight piled on (getting the thing moving is the trick with those) to the inclined plane sleds that just winch the weight box up a slope as you proceed down the track, to ones like Southern Shaker with an adjustable pan. They also have sleds with measuring gear right on the rig and they just move the reflector to behind the starting point. The key to a good pull is balance, for sure, but all that balance needs to feed momentum as the pan-drop/wheel lift happen at set times/distances, but they take time to happen and the faster you're moving when they do, the further down the track you get.
As you found out, there is a LOT to the sport that isn't apparent to the casual viewer and given the stubborn prejudices of many people these days, they just don't see the intelligence and education of the people running and participating in these events.

The physics behind how the hitch point height affects the tractor is something that seems to need to be explained a bit here. The lower the hitch point, the less the front end gets pulled upwards. It counteracts the torque that the motor applies to the rear wheels, which is trying to pull a wheelie when pulling a heavy load with good traction. In normal tractor work this is part of the genius of how the three point hitch system helps keep tractors from pulling wheelies when pulling plows and the like.
In these competitions, you want to get max traction on the rear wheels. So getting all the weight on the rear wheels is desirable. You want to pull a slight wheelie. Put the hitch point too low and your front wheels will never leave the ground and you will not get max traction on the rear wheels.
Of course this a balancing act. If your front wheels lift too easy, you'll either dig the rear skids into the ground and reduce your traction and increase the resistance against forward motion. Or you'll have to back off the throttle to keep that from happening. Either will reduce your forward momentum.

Reminded me of the BAJA college competition I was participating in as a part of the uniersity team quite a while back (2014). We had a Towing event where we had to put a 1.8ton truck about 15m with our little handmade ATV. Since it was the first time this particular event was held, the rules were a little unrefined as this towing event. So, our ATV had a horizontal bar running just across the back of the vehicle, which was conviently placed well over a 50cm above the axle. (Just becuase we couldnt afford stiffer materials at the time). And so hooking the truck to that bar, gave us a super advantage over the competition, as the rest of the teams were running lightweight & stronger composite steel with less components required for bracing its own weight.
However, our ATV's weight (around 450kgs) with a soft setup & the placement of the tow bar on our ATV gave us the 1st place in the event. Simple wonderful

Note that the height of the axle is not significant, it is the height of the hitch from the ground, which is why it is that that is regulated. As in drag racing, you do the calculations from ground level,  tyre size does not affect the geometry. Of course in drag racing it is the height of the CofG above the ground, rather than the hitch.

One can find A LOT of technicalities in any undertaking. This doesn't make tractor pullers smart, it makes them well versed.
Back in the early days of automobiles, you had mechanics tuning engines too. They weren't smart, they just tried things until they worked and they knew the basics:

More fuel + More air + Better timing + Higher compression + Higher revs = MORE POWER.

And so they went by those guidelines to make engines suck more fuel and air, have tighter timings with higher quality fuels.
They used stronger blocks and pistons to allow for higher compression as they made the air/fuel intakes smoother and the space between the piston and cylinder head narrower for higher compression and then they used lighter parts for higher revs.

Doesn't make them smart, just makes them capable of using parts designed by actually smart people.

Hey Destin, I'm a long time puller and pulling goes way back in my family as far as horse pulling before tractors. Before there was a weight transfer sled, tractor pullers had to pull a metal plate that as you go down the track, people step on the plate and ride it down making it heavier as it goes. That was not the most efficient due to people changing all through the night and reasons you can guess. Eventually someone created the weight transfer sled because it was the same for every puller.

I noticed something that I don't have a word for. I'm from the deep south, northeast Florida. When I graduated high school and went out into the world, one of my first jobs was in a tech support call center. I noticed that about half my callers would ask me, "Where are you from?" When I'd say, "Florida," they'd say, "Yeah, I can tell from that accent." So I worked at it. I got rid of my southern accent completely. Those questions got less and less frequent. When it did happen, the response was different, "Really? I couldn't tell. You don't have an accent of any kind." I fixed it.

However, when I go home and I'm around my family, the y'alls and aints start to creep back into my vocabulary. I start to get the drawl back a little.

Destin has an accent in his videos. But I could tell he was fighting it sometimes in this video. He was trying hard not to go full on southern accent being around it so much. It's a weird thing. 9:12 "That's what we do." "No. No. No. Right hand. Right hand." "Look me in the eye." "Thank you, Will."

And that is EXACTLY what happens to every Southern child, hundreds of times, until they get it right. Every single adult you meet is your parent when it comes to handshakes and general respect. You learn EXACTLY how to start and end a conversation. "Community parenting" is a still very much in practice today in the South. This is how the "Southern Gentleman" is made, but nobody really talks about the "Southern Lady" is from the same cloth. Go down to South Carolina and when meeting a lady during the work day, she will do the exact same thing.
Eye contact is pivotal. People that don't learn these things until their 20's are obvious to people that learn it in their childhood, because they tend to over compensate.

It's simple, simultaneously;; eye contact, thumb web contact, grip once with no strong squeeze, ONE pump, shake away laterally, and the person that extended their hand first introduces first.
More than one pump has different meanings. But a basic meeting comes immediately afterwards at 10:16.
